## Academic Analysis of Marriage and Sexuality in Reymont's "Chłopi"

The Peasants (Polish: Chłopi) is a novel written by the Polish author Władysław Reymont in four parts between 1904 and 1909. Władysław Reymont received the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature for this work.

### Character Relationships and Sexual Dynamics

Maciej Boryna – the richest man in the village and the main character of the novel. ... Jagna – a beautiful 19-year-old girl and the main female character represents the central triangle of desire that drives the novel's conflict.

To help her family prospects Jagna reluctantly agrees to marry Maciej Boryna, despite being romantically involved with his son, Antek, who himself is a married man. This arrangement creates a complex web of relationships that challenges traditional moral boundaries.

### Symbolism and Academic Interpretation

Symbolism - the use of symbols to represent ideas, especially in art and literature (the scene of the Maciej's death, which symbolises a strong relationship between people and nature).(no content)Jagna Paczesianka/Borynowa – młoda, piękna kobieta o niezwykłej urodzie i zmysłowej naturze; niepasująca do sztywnych ram społeczności wiejskiej, staje się ofiarą własnej niezależności i niezdolności do podporządkowania się konwenansom. Jagna's character serves as a symbol of natural instinct clashing with social conventions.

### Marriage as Social Institution

Córka pozostawia decyzję matce, która - słysząc o hojnym zapisie na rzecz Jagny - zgadza się na zaręczyny. The marriage arrangements demonstrate how economic considerations often outweighed romantic feelings in rural Polish society.

Perhaps Jagna's biggest flaw flows from her inability to understand the role of social norms and, more pragmatically, wealth and property.

### Sexuality and Social Judgment

The male attention she gets is often undesired and the other women in the community gradually start to perceive her comportment with men as a source of depravation. This is an unfair division of blame – after all, the men pining after her are responsible for their indiscretions at least to the same degree as Jagna.(no content)Tymczasem Jagna, której zmysłowa natura szuka ujścia, nawiązuje nową relację – tym razem z młodym, wykształconym organistą. Ta znajomość ma charakter nie tylko zmysłowy, ale także duchowy – organista wprowadza Jagnę w świat sztuki, czyta jej książki, pokazuje reprodukcje obrazów.

### Mythological Parallels

The academic analysis reveals mythological underpinnings: Główny wątek, osnuty wokół postaci Macieja, jego syna Antka i pożądanej przez obu Jagny, zawiera elementy jednego z najbardziej znanych mitów – mitu o wojnie trojańskiej. Jagna jest odpowiedniczką pięknej Heleny, Maciej – jej męża Menelaosa, Antek zaś Parysa.

### Seasonal Symbolism

Each of the four parts represents a season in the life of the peasants – Autumn (published in 1904), Winter (published in 1904), Spring (published in 1906), and Summer (published in 1909). This division underlines the relationship of human life with nature.

The novel's structure mirrors natural cycles, with the characters' sexual and emotional lives following the rhythm of the seasons, reinforcing themes of human connection to nature and the cyclical nature of desire, marriage, and death in rural Polish society.
